title: Alan Adler's Original Method
preparation_steps: Place a paper filter in the cap and rinse it.
Assemble AeroPress in standard position on a sturdy mug.
Grind 14g (one scoop) of coffee fine (like table salt).
Heat water to 80°C (175°F) - much cooler than usual!

brewing_steps.audio_script: Start the timer. Pour hot water quickly to the number 2 circle on the chamber. This uses about 130 grams of water at 80 degrees Celsius. The low temperature is key for sweetness.
Grab your paddle and stir briskly for 10 seconds. This rapid agitation ensures all grounds are wet and extraction happens quickly.

Insert the plunger and press gently. Don't push too hard; let the air pressure do the work. Stop as soon as you hear the hiss. You now have a concentrated coffee that you can dilute with hot water or milk to taste.

what_to_expect.description: This is the method recommended by Alan Adler, the inventor of the AeroPress. It defies modern specialty coffee norms by using a very short brew time and low water temperature (80°C). The result is a sweet, low-acidity concentrate that mimics espresso strength, intended to be diluted with water (Americano style) or milk.
what_to_expect.audio_script: This is the original recipe by Alan Adler, the inventor of the AeroPress. It uses a fine grind, a short brew time, and surprisingly cool water at 80 degrees Celsius. This combination reduces acidity and bitterness, producing a sweet, concentrated shot perfect for diluting with water or milk.

notes: Add hot water to the cup after brewing to make a full cup (Americano), or add hot milk for a latte style drink.
